doc.title: Monthly CPI: Headline inflation in Australia's monthly CPI rebounded 90bps to \(2.8\%\) yoy in July, above expectations. Inflation in the trimmed- mean measure rebounded 60bps to \(2.7\%\) yoy, also a

passages.text: Monthly CPI: Headline inflation in Australia's monthly CPI rebounded 90bps to \(2.8\%\) yoy in July, above expectations. Inflation in the trimmed- mean measure rebounded 60bps to \(2.7\%\) yoy, also above our forecast, although it remained within the RBAs \(2 - 3\%\) target band for the eighth consecutive month.

RBA Minutes: The Minutes from August's meeting highlighted the "unanimous" and "strong case" to lower the cash rate 25bps to \(3.60\%\) . With no discussion of leaving rates on hold, the debate focused on the potential pace of cuts going forward, with arguments raised in support of both an ongoing gradual pace of cuts and a faster pace of cuts.

Private Capex: Private capex edged up \(0.2\%\) qoq in 2Q2025, retracing the downwardly- revised \(0.2\%\) qoq contraction in the prior quarter. Growth was subdued across both buildings & structures and machinery & equipment, although outcomes were more mixed across industries.

Construction Activity: Construction activity increased \(3.0\%\) qoq in 2Q2025, above expectations. The rise was driven by a surge in private non- residential construction, while residential investment was little changed in the quarter.
Credit: Total private- sector credit growth picked up to \(0.7\%\) mom in July, slightly above expectations.

Australia: Mon: Business Indicators, Cotality House Prices, Building Approvals, ANZ- Indeed Job Ads, MI Inflation Gauge, S&P Global Mfg PMI; Tues: Balance of Payments, Government. Eiance Statistics; Wed: 2Q2025 GDP, Speech by RBA Governor Bullock (titled Technology, Trust, and the Future of Central Banking in Australia; 6:00pm AEST), S&P Global Services & Composite PMIs; Thurs: Household Spending, Trade Balance, Reuters News Interview with RBA Deputy Governor Hayder; Fri: Foreign Reserves.
New Zealand: Mon: Building Permits; Tues: Terms of Trade; Wed: Cotality House Prices; ANZ Commodity Prices; Thurs: Building Work.
In Australia, the focus will be on 2Q2025 GDP. We expect GDP to increase \(0.5\%\) qoq, taking the year- ended rate to \(1.6\%\) yoy. We will also receive more timely updates on
household spending, housing market and trade balance.
In New Zealand, we will receive updates on the housing market and trade prices.
Cotality Capital City Dwelling Prices (8- city, nsa), Last: \(+0.6\% \text{mm}\) , \(+1.8\% \text{qqq}\) , \(+3.0\% \text{yoy}\) ; GSe: \(+0.6\% \text{mm}\) .

Australian capital- city dwelling prices increased a further \(0.6\% \text{mm}\) in July, marking the sixth consecutive month of positive growth. The increase was broadly based across capital cities, with Darwin and Perth recording the largest increases. Looking ahead to August, daily data are pointing to a further \(0.6\% \text{mm}\) increase.
Exhibit 1: Growth in house prices held steady across capital cities in July
Source: Cotality, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Company profits, Last: \(- 0.5\% \text{qqq}\) , \(- 5.0\% \text{yoy}\) ; GSe: \(0.0\% \text{qqq}\) ; Bloomberg consensus: \(+1.6\% \text{qqq}\) .
Non- farm inventory volumes, Last: \(+0.8\% \text{qqq}\) , \(+0.7\% \text{yoy}\) ; GSe: \(- 0.1\% \text{qqq}\) ; Bloomberg consensus: \(+0.4\% \text{qqq}\) .
Corporate profits fell \(0.5\% \text{qqq}\) in 1Q2025, against expectations for an increase. The decline was driven by a sharp fall in mining profits, while non- mining profits rose in the quarter.

Looking forward, we expect corporate profits to be flat in 2Q2025, weighed down by weaker mining profits and commodity prices. We expect growth in wages and salaries to ease to \(1.2\% \text{qqq}\) given slightly softer WPI growth, while inventories are expected to
edge \(0.1\%\) qoq lower.
Exhibit 2: The mining industry weighed on gross operating profits in 102025
Source:ABS,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Total residential building approvals, Last: \(11.9\%\) mom, \(27.4\%\) yoy; GSe: \(- 5.0\%\) mom; Bloomberg consensus: \(- 5.1\%\) mom.

Residential building rose a further \(11.9\%\) mom in June, above expectations. That said, the increase was driven solely by the volatile, high- density dwelling sector, while approvals for detached housing continued to contract. Looking ahead, we expect approvals to contract \(5.0\%\) mom in July after recording sharp rises in the high- density dwelling sector over recent months.
Exhibit 3: Approvals for detached housing remain somewhat subdued
Source:ABS,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Current account, Last: \(- A\$ 14.7bn (- 2.1\%\) of GDP); GSe: \(- A\$ 17.8bn; Bloomberg consensus: \(- A\$ 16.0bn\) .
Net export contribution to GDP, Last: \(- 0.1\) ppt; GSe: \(+0.3\) ppt; Bloomberg consensus: \(+0.1\) ppt.

Australia's current account deficit narrowed to A\$14.7bn in 1Q2025. The deficit was larger- than- expected in the quarter and followed a A\$3.8bn revision to reflect an even larger deficit of A\$16.3bn in 4Q2024. In real terms, net exports subtracted 0.1ppt from GDP growth in 1Q2025, against expectations for a neutral impact.

Looking ahead, we expect the current account deficit to widen to A\$17.8bn in 2Q2025, reflecting weaker export values on the back of soft commodity prices. That said, in real terms, we expect net exports to add 30bp to 2Q2025 GDP growth.
Exhibit 4: Australia's current account deficit narrowed slightly to -A\$14.7bn from an upwardly revised -A\$16.3bn

Australian GDP increased \(0.2\%\) qoq in 1Q2025, with year- ended growth unchanged at \(1.3\%\) yoy. On a per capita basis, GDP contracted for the 8th time in the past 9 quarters. Compositionally, domestic demand growth edged \(0.2\%\) qoq higher, with a modest lift in construction activity offset by a fall in equipment spending and a softening trend in consumer spending. Public demand also contracted, for only the second time over the past 7 years.

Looking ahead to 2Q2025, we expect a slight acceleration in GDP growth to \(0.5\%\) qoq, which would take the year- ended rate to \(1.6\%\) yoy. In per capita terms, we expect GDP to remain broadly unchanged.

Compositionally, we forecast a pick- up in consumption growth \((+0.6\%\) qoq), reflecting an improvement in more timely retail and household spending data. We also note that State- level electricity subsidies in QLD and WA were mostly used up over 2Q2025 – which should result in a boost to household consumption and an offsetting fall in public consumption, with no net effect on GDP.
Private investment is expected to edge higher \((+0.1\%\) qoq), with a sequential improvement in equipment investment but sharp slowdowns in dwelling investment and

non- dwelling construction. We expect public demand to rebound \((+0.7\% \text{qq})\) following a contraction in the prior quarter. Net exports are expected to add 30bp to GDP growth, though we expect inventories to subtract a similar amount from growth. Separately, productivity looks to have increased slightly over 2Q2025 given that hours worked expanded at a slower pace than our GDP forecast.

Overall, we view the balance of risks to our forecast as two- sided and flag large uncertainties around inventories and public demand. We will finalise our 2Q2025 tracking estimate following the release of Balance of Payments and Government Finance Statistics next Tuesday.
Exhibit 5: Rate-sensitive components of GDP are showing tentative signs of recovery
\\* We estimate rate-sensitive components to be a function of private consumption, investment and imports.
Source: ABS, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Nominal household spending, Last: \(+0.5\% \text{mm}\) ; GSe: \(+0.6\% \text{mm}\) ; Bloomberg consensus: \(+0.5\% \text{mm}\) .

The ABS Household Spending Indicator increased \(0.5\% \text{mm}\) in June, below expectations for a larger increase, with the year- ended rate accelerating 40bp to \(4.8\% \text{yo}\) . Compositionally, the increase was driven by equally large \(0.5\% \text{mm}\) increases across discretionary spending and non- discretionary spending.

Looking ahead, we expect household spending to rise a further \(0.6\% \text{mm}\) in July, with large sporting events in the month boosting spending across the recreation and hospitality categories. Our forecast is slightly weaker than timely card spending data published by CBA and NAB, which point to \(0.8\% \text{mm}\) and \(0.7\% \text{mm}\) increases respectively. This largely reflects our view that the pull- back in household goods and clothing spending (following EOFY sales in June) will be larger than the card spending data suggest.
Exhibit 6: Discretionary and non-discretionary spending both picked up in June
Source:ABS,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Goods Trade Balance, Last: \(+A\) 5.4bn; GSe: \(+A\) 4.8bn; Bloomberg consensus: \(+A\) 5.0bn.

Australia's goods trade surplus widened by \(A\) 3.8bn to \(+A\) 5.4bn in June, above expectations. The increase was driven by a rise in exports of the volatile non- monetary gold component, as well as a sharp decline in goods imports.
Looking ahead, we expect the goods trade surplus to narrow \(A\) 0.6bn to \(+A\) 4.8bn in July, driven by a rebound in goods imports.
Exhibit 7: Goods import values fell across all categories in June after rising in May

Goldman Sachs conducts a global full- service, integrated investment banking, investment management, and brokerage business. LLC, the United States broker dealer, is a member of SIPC (https://www.sipc.org).

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

This research is focused on investment themes across markets, industries and sectors. It does not attempt to distinguish between the prospects or performance of, or provide analysis of, individual companies within any industry or sector we describe.

Any trading recommendation in this research relating to an equity or credit security or securities within an industry or sector is reflective of the investment theme being discussed and is not a recommendation of any such security in isolation.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character-risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm disclosures. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
